Expectation1: Maintain passenger safety and provide assistance during service.
Situation1: The passenger emergency alarm has been activated due to a medical emergency in the train.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: A poll worker requests that the voter re-sign a smudged envelope so the ballot will not risk rejection later.
Story:
I was nearing the end of my shift as a subway operator when the emergency alarm blared through my headset. A passenger had collapsed in the third car, and protocol demanded I stay calm, alert emergency services, and provide assistance if needed. My heart pounded as I prepared to leave the operator’s cabin, but just then, my phone buzzed—a reminder that I had only minutes left to cast my vote at the nearby polling station. I rushed over during my break, determined to fulfill my civic duty.

Inside the polling station, I hurriedly filled out my ballot, but as I sealed the envelope, a poll worker noticed the signature was smudged. “Please re-sign, or your vote might not count,” she said gently. I glanced at the clock, torn. My radio crackled with updates about the medical emergency on my train, and I knew my presence was needed. Yet, the poll worker’s eyes were insistent, reminding me of the importance of following every instruction to ensure my vote was valid. I stood frozen, caught between the urgent needs of my passengers and my responsibility as a voter, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in on me.
